instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
Hi All,

let me start with introducing myself, I'm an electronics engineer working in software now for ASML. I started repairing macbooks (actually Louis videos triggered me ;-) ) from a hobby perspective now and then but it has grown since to 1 or 2 a week. My repair side carrier made it possible to invest in proper tooling (trinocular microscoop, JBC soldering, Quick hotair, HP multimeter, power supply with dual 30v5A, i5 hackintosh workstation from Aliexpress :-D


I'm working on a case (read rabbit-hole) for data recovery of an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, i'll try to be as elaborate as possible (most from memory)

when I received the board it was doing absolutely nothing. I took some pictures of the corrosion and ultrasonically cleaned the board. this revealed some problem areas.
a lot of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_GH</SIGNAL> circuit was broken/gone, replaced some resistors and removed some caps. It works now (doesn't look very nice since i only had 0603 resistors laying around)

[ATTACH type="full"]59347[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full"]59348[/ATTACH]
the gone pads are TPAD testpoints/via's, didn't bother fixing those yet

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_GH</SIGNAL>, repaired the circuit and now 3,4v present (when powered via F7000)
still no power via USB-C (stays at 5v 0mA, other port 5v 50mA and getting hot)
first replaced one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (the one getting hot) , still not equal mA, replaced second <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, now both equal. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_3GH</SIGNAL> present at <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> (usb 5v 10mA)
I did not trust the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> (ISL) (weird impedance at <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>) so replaced it
now Aux det is 1,2v and <RESISTOR>R7015</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7016</RESISTOR> measure ok.
now I get 5v at charger and 40mA cycling at both USB ports, but ISL still creates no PPBUS (12v3)

when I supply power to the battery terminal, (7v5) it takes 15mA and I measure this voltage also at F7000 (tried 10v, no change), PPBUS is than equal to the supplied voltage

<SIGNAL>SMS_RESET_R_L</SIGNAL> = 3,4v at <RESISTOR>R7072</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_GH</SIGNAL> = 5v at <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL> = 3,4v at <RESISTOR>R7071</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_3GH_UPC</SIGNAL> = 3v3 at <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR>

Any clues where to look further?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is the only corroded area on the board?

STOP applying external voltage at F7000, or battery terminals!!!

Are you sure the new <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips are good?
Many fake/remarked chinese crap out.
Check for 1V1 LDO voltage on the powered USB-C port.
Do you get <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> too?

"power supply with dual 30v5A"
Forget it and get a simple 24V/20A, or arm one with DPS5020.
Many times mentioned WHY in the forum...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
Hi, 

thanks for the fast reply, 

The ISL area was a bit corroded, after cleaning with IPA and a brush it looked ok. but replaced the ISL (ebay source) after measuring some wierd levels

I ordered two batches of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, first 5pcs from ali that arrived after 2months dangling in a plastic bag wrapped in bubble foil (awful), and a set from ebay, nicely packed in a cut reel (15eu a piece). What would be a trustworthy source (available in EU) for the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.

I'll have a look into the signals mentioned and get back to it

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 63226, member: 682"]
First of all, welcome to the forum!

<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is the only corroded area on the board?

STOP applying external voltage at F7000, or battery terminals!!!

Are you sure the new <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips are good?
Many fake/remarked chinese crap out.
Check for 1V1 LDO voltage on the powered USB-C port.
Do you get <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> too?

"power supply with dual 30v5A"
Forget it and get a simple 24V/20A, or arm one with DPS5020.
Many times mentioned WHY in the forum...
[/QUOTE]


I checked the 1v1 LDO both are 0v
<SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3v42

I swapped out the aliexpress <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> for one I bought on ebay (the ones which where packed in a cut reel) I see also difference in the chips caps, the one from Ali are shiny-ish and the eBay ones have are more dull finish but all of them are reballed. the og chips are shiny (like the Ali batch)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
Quote the text you want to make a refference.
I don't see the reason to quote an entire post...

You need to get 1V1 LDO on all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
I'm still trying to find a serious provider, is not easy.
Is better to buy the "wings" board, like this
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.aliexpress.com/item/32957303042.html?spm=a2g0o.productlist.0.0.3bdc686aWMqs8m&algo_pvid=97db8548-edd1-4166-9bfd-23fbfa045b8a&algo_expid=97db8548-edd1-4166-9bfd-23fbfa045b8a-25&btsid=0b0a119a15968937165805667ec72f&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_,searchweb201603_[/URL]
being original for sure.
Still exists the risk that initial problem was a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.
If you buy many, probably get 80-90% good ones...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
When 1v1 is not present, is that a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> issue ( broken) or could that be an issue elsewhere? Are there any additional checks i could do to verify a bad <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.

I use 425degrC and high air to (de)solder them could this be of any risk (i also do eg tristar with these settings and i'm successful with that)

when salvaging <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s I guess I need to reball, any suggestion for a stencil?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.aliexpress.com/item/32988100783.html?spm=a2g0o.productlist.0.0.41162498MvBSBO&algo_pvid=857dc8c1-a492-4880-90cb-276b91e29b16&algo_expid=857dc8c1-a492-4880-90cb-276b91e29b16-21&btsid=0b0a050b15969084390257581e7a4a&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_,searchweb201603_[/URL]

[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.ebay.com/itm/CD3215C00-ZQZR-CYPD4155-96BZXI-TPS65983BAZBHR-CYPD4155-9-BGA96-Stencil-Template-/273772783856[/URL]

Use direct heat stencil, with solder paste.
Practice on scrap board, until get confiance.
1V1 LDO should appear on the powered USB port only.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
i'll look into that, thanks for the advise.

Like mentioned earlier, this repair is for data recovery, is there another way of retrieving data from the ssd (encrypted), This model has a replacable SSD in a weird form-factor

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
Insert SSD into other machine, with similar connector.
00840/875 have the same pin layout...
